facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 181 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 181 of 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on 16th October 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 16th October, 1952, from the decision dated the 22nd December, 1952,

facts.text: Appeal from decision dated September 22 1952 of Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from a decision dated September 22, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal decision in Appeals Nos. Cal. 366/51, Cal. 69/52 and Cal. 70/52.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 16th October, 1952, from the decision dated the 22nd December, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta in Appeals Nos. Cal. 366/51, Cal. 69/52 and Cal. 70/52,

facts.text: Arising out of award dated February 9 1952 of Chairman Industrial Tribunal Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the award dated the 9th February, 1952, of the Chairman, Industrial Tribunal, Delhi.

facts.text: Appellant is Punjab National Bank Ltd. Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi  hereinafter referred to as the Bank

facts.text: Respondents are workmen represented by their Union.

anchor.surface_text: and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union.

facts.text: Disputes between parties referred on February 21 1950 to Industrial Tribunal presided by Sri K. S. Campbell-Puri.

anchor.surface_text: Several other disputes between the parties had already been referred on February 21, 1950, to another Industrial Tribunal presided over by Sri K. S. Campbell-Puri,

facts.text: Bank alleged respondents along with other workmen numbering more than a thousand commenced general strike on April 18 1951 during pendency of proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: and during the pendency of the proceedings before the said Tribunal, the Bank alleged that the respondents along with other workmen numbering more than a thousand illegally companymenced a general strike on April 18,1951,

facts.text: Strike was in connection with a fresh dispute.

anchor.surface_text: in companynection with a fresh dispute.

facts.text: Notice issued to strikers to return to work by April 24 1951 or deemed to have left service.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, numberice was issued to the strikers that unless they returned to work by April 24, 1951, they would be deemed to have left service of their own accord.

facts.text: Strikers ignored the notice.

anchor.surface_text: That numberice having been ignored by the strikers

facts.text: Second notice issued on April 27 1951 terminating service of strikers.

anchor.surface_text: a second numberice was issued to them on April 27, 1951, terminating their service.

facts.text: Government of India intervened after strike.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India thereupon intervened,

facts.text: Bank agreed to take back all employees except 150 against whom objections for subversive activities and other conduct.

anchor.surface_text: and as a result of the discussions held between the Government officials and the Bank, the latter agreed to take back all the employees except 150 against whom the Bank had objections on account of their alleged subversive activities and other objectionable and unlawful companyduct before and during the strike.

facts.text: Government of India constituted Tribunal on July 2 1951 to decide questions regarding dismissals of 150 employees.

anchor.surface_text: On July 2, 1951, the Government of India companystituted a Tribunal to decide the questions regarding the dismissals etc. of the aforesaid 150 employees,

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal made award on February 9 1952 refusing reinstatement on ground of illegal strike contravening section 23(b) of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: and that Tribunal, after calling for the statements of case on behalf of the parties and hearing them, made an award on February 9, 1951, refusing reinstatement on the sole ground that the respondents had gone on an illegal strike in companytravention of section 23 b  of the Industrial Disputes Act,

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held Bank entitled to dismiss respondents due to illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Bank was entitled to dismiss them.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal granted compensation to respondents at half salary rates from dismissal to publication of award.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, granted to the respondents companypensation byway of salary and allowances at half the rates from the date of dismissal to the date of the publication of the award.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal at Calcutta

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal agreed strike was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: which, while agreeing with the Industrial Tribunal that the strike was illegal,

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held strike condoned by Bank.

anchor.surface_text: held that it was companydoned by the Bank and it was, therefore, number open to it to justify the dismissal of the respondents on the ground that they had participated in the illegal strike.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held dismissal wrongful as no charges framed for violence or subversive activities and no explanation called for.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal further held that the dismissal of the respondents was wrongful because numbercharges were framed against any of them in respect of their alleged acts of violence or subversive activities and their explanation was number called for.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on April 10 1953 by Patanjali Sastri C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. April 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by PATANJALI SASTRI C. J.-

facts.text: No permission obtained under section 33 for dismissal during pendency of proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, numbersuch permission was obtained.

facts.text: Strike illegal under section 23(b) due to pendency before Campbell-Puri Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: If the pendency of the proceedings before Sri Campbell-Puri made the strike of the respondents illegal under section 23 b  of the Act,

facts.text: Dismissal illegal under section 33 without permission.

anchor.surface_text: the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining his permission as required by section 33 was also illegal.

Appeal by special leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 16th October, 1952, from the decision dated the 22nd December, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta in Appeals Nos. Cal. 366/51, Cal. 69/52 and Cal. 70/52, arising out of the award dated the 9th February, 1952, of the Chairman, Industrial Tribunal, Delhi.

This is an appeal by special leave from a decision dated September 22, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta setting aside an award dated February 9, 1952, made by the Industrial Tribunal constituted to adjudicate on certain disputes between the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi  hereinafter referred to as the Bank  and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union.

section 23 b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, and that the Bank was entitled to dismiss them. The Tribunal, however, granted to the respondents compensation byway of salary and allowances at half the rates from the date of dismissal to the date of the publication of the award.

issues.text: the question of condonation or waiver of the illegal strike

anchor.surface_text: We consider it unnecessary to express any opinion on the question of condonation or waiver of the illegal strike for, assuming that there was no such condonation or waiver and it was open to the Bank to rely upon the illegal strike as a valid ground for dismissing the respondents,

issues.text: whether the Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents

anchor.surface_text: section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, furnishes a short answer to the further contention that the Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents. That section provides, inter alia, that no employer shall, during the pendency of any proceedings before a tribunal in respect of any industrial dispute, discharge by way of dismissal or otherwise, any workman concerned in the dispute save with the permission in writing of the said Tribunal.

issues.text: whether the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining permission as required by section 33 was illegal

anchor.surface_text: If the pendency of the proceedings before Sri Campbell-Puri made the strike of the respondents illegal under section 23 b  of the Act, the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining his permission as required by section 33 was also illegal. We see no force in the argument of the AttorneyGeneral that the section has no application to the case as strikes and lock-outs are dealt with in a different chapter,

issues.text: whether section 33 has application to the case given that strikes are dealt with in Chapter V and respondents were not concerned in the disputes pending adjudication before Sri Campbell-Puri

anchor.surface_text: Chapter V, and as the respondents were no concerned in the disputes pending adjudication before Sri Campbell-Puri. The terms of section 33 are wide enough to cover the present case, and the fact that it finds place in Chapter VII headed Miscellaneous is by no means inconsistent with its general application to all cases of discharge on whatever ground it may be based. This is shown by the recent amendment of the section by Act XLVIII of 1950 which has omitted the words except for misconduct unconnected with the dispute in the newly substituted section.
